text: A Susskind-type MODERATOR is speaking into camera:

Tonight we'll discuss a subject most of us seem to consider either bad taste or frivolous or funny. But if our experts are right, we face what might be called a masculinity crisis. Every fourth American man uptight, threatened by the increasing sexual demands of American women...
An IRATE WOMAN speaks into camera:
They always put it that way, but well, all it means, you know, is every fourth American woman's never satisfied. That's it. I never am -- have been, you know...
A COOL WOMAN speaks into camera:
This, this image of the, the man eating woman. It isn't our increasing demands. I think it's the shrinking American male...
A SAD WOMAN speaks into camera:
No, I never had, well, whatever it is you call it. But the hours he works, I can't blame him...
Full frame -- a scandal sheet picture of a sex-starved wi naked while her husband sleeps, captioned I BUY WHAT MY HUSBAND CAN'T GIVE.

... but it's a problem. A big problem. With so many women I know... Camera pulls back to show the picture among other pinups women -- rich, beautiful or naked, but all blonde -- stea wilted on the wall over a dishwashing machine. JOE BUCK g at the wall as he scrapes garbage.
Just keep your pants on, ladies...
A LADY COMMENTATOR, gradually surrounded by lonely women.

Before World War One -- American men outnumbered women by over six percent. Today American women not only outnumber men, but live five years longer -- leaving them in control of vast corporate wealth and seventy-five percent of America's purchasing power... The Lady Commentator is replaced by Joe, stacking dishes, surrounded by frustrated ladies. He laughs tolerantly.
Y'all,line up and take your turn...
The Moderator smiles into camera.
My question is this -- will American know-how come up with a marketable male to replace all the men who are worrying themselves into an early grave over women's increasing sexual demands?
Joe sings as he soaps himself, "Whoopee ti yi yo, git alo little dogies, for you know New York will be your new hom Sound and image freeze on Joe's open mouth.
TITLES follow as indicated, sound and action continuing a each credit.
Joe's song continues over a sweating WAITRESS, glancing u
Where's that Joe Buck?

Wrapped in a towel, singing in front of his dresser mirro Joe sprays himself with deodorant, aiming a last playful blast at the unseen crotch -- freezing song and image as CREDITS continue over... ... a calendar girl on the wall blushing orange, mouth fr in a tiny O, staring wide-eyed. Joe's song continues as.. ... Joe rips the wrapping from a new Stetson and sets it his head, freezing song and image as CREDITS continue.
RALPH, an aging black man, faces a mountain of dirty dish
Where's that Joe Buck?
Singing as he buttons his new cowboy shirt, Joe interrupt himself to answer Ralph...
Yeah, where's that Joe Buck? ... continuing his song as he pulls up and zips his tight thighed black slacks, freezing song and image for CREDITS
SALLY BUCK, a pretty middle-aged blonde, smiles down at camera,
You look real nice, Joe baby...
Joe sings as he pulls on his new cowboy boots, arranging cuffs to show off the yellow sunburst at the ankle, freez song and image for CREDITS.
The pink MANAGER scowls at his pocket watch.
Where's that Joe Buck?
Joe hums as he piles a complete wardrobe of cowboy clothe still in their wrappers, into a shiny new suitcase of bla and white horsehide.
Yeah, where's that Joe Buck?
Holding his watch, the Manager wags a finger at camera.
You're due here at four o'clock. Look at those dishes, look!
Joe laughs as he locks his suitcase.

Know what you can do with those dishes? And if you ain't man enough to do it yourself, I'd be happy to oblige... Joe picks up his suitcase, a portable transistor radio, w away from the mirror, then pauses to run a comb through h hair, hook a cigarette at the corner of his mouth and str a match on his thumbnail before he turns back for one admiring glance at himself in the mirror -- proud, exulta ready -- freezing the image as CREDITS END.
Joe leaves the hotel, carrying his suitcase.
The pink Manager points at his watch angrily.
Four to midnight, understand? Angle widens to include Joe, holding his suitcase and rad Ralph stares at him curiously, stacking dishes.
Say, look, uh, I gotta have a word with you, if you got a second.
Later. Later maybe. The Manager hurries away, carrying a basket of dishes.
You ain't coming to work?
Don't guess. Just come for my day's pay owing and to tell you I'm heading East. Joe tilts his Stetson as the Waitress appears at the door
Cups! ... but she disappears without noticing Joe. Ralph offers hand. Joe takes it, holds it.
What you gonna do back there, East?
Lotta rich women back there...
Yeah?
Men, they mostly faggots.
Must be some mess back there.
Well, ain't no use hanging around here.
Ain't gonna collect your pay?
I got me two hundred twenty-four bucks of flat folding money...  (slaps hip)
He know what he can do with that chicken-shit day's pay. And if he ain't man enough to do it for himself, I be happy to oblige!

The door marked EMPLOYEES ONLY swings open and Joe appear measuring his effect on the customers and his fellow employees as he crosses the sterile white dining room, observing the drab details of the life he has left behind garbage on greasy dishes, limp food in steam table trays, coffee-soaked cigarette butts, caked mustard and ketchup formica table tops -- two pimply high school girls slurpi suggestive noises after Joe through the straws of empty c glasses. O.S. a Tiomkin-tradition chorus sings, "From thi valley they say you are going -- we will miss your bright eyes and sweet smile for they say you are taking the sunshine..."
The song ends as Joe comes from the cafeteria "... that brightened our pathway a while."

Tough tiddy, ladies, you had your chance. From a high angle -- Joe starts his long walk toward the depot along the street of a small Western town struggling urbanize itself. The click-clack-click of his boots is lo but somehow lonely The radio at his ear drones grain pric on the Commodity change. Joe's pace slows as he passes...

... a gilt-lettered sign in the window, glittering in the sun, momentarily hiding the fact that the shop is deserte Joe grins as he hears remembered sounds and voices incomp flashes, more significant in tone than content a girl giggling sexily -- "Keep your meat hooks off my beauty operators, sugar" -- tinkling noises of a busy beauty par - Sally Buck singing "Hush, little baby, don't say a word Grammaw gonna buy you a mockingbird..." ... a shift of light revealing a row of tarnished driers, broken mirror, a FOR RENT sign in the window. Joe turns toward the bus depot, radio pressed to his ear.
Benson and Hedges One Hundreds makes special awards from time to time for anything that's longer than anything...
Care to get out your yardstick, gentlemen? At the same moment, a recognizable variant of the "Big Country" theme blares loud.
Gary Cooper (or John Wayne) walks a frontier street.
High angle of the departing bus, intercut "Big Country" fashion, alternating high shots with close-ups of the bus wheals.
Through the bus windshield -- a dizzying montage of traff lines, arrows and signs as the bus sweeps around and up o the freeway.

Joe sits at the front, opposite the driver, cracking his as he watches the huge billboards streaking by, promising power, happiness and beautiful women if he chooses the ri breakfast food, hair oil or automobile. Joe listens to th humming tires, the roar of the engine, shaking his head.

This is a powerful mothah, ain't it? Ignored by the driver, Joe rises and walks back to his em double seat, glancing around to see what impression he's on his immediate fellow travelers -- an OLD LADY in front him -- a hostile young sailor with acne behind him -- two teeny-boppers flirting with Joe hysterically -- a PALE BL directly across the aisle, smiling at Joe weakly.
Do you have a stick of gum? Joe leans across, snapping his gum as he offers her a sti He watches her nibble it daintily on her front teeth.
Thank you.
Plenty more where that came from.
Thank you, no, it's just till the Dramamine works. I get carsick.
I only get carsick on boats.  (waits, then)

But seems to me that's more the fish smell than the bouncing... Joe realizes that her eyes are closed. Mildly depressed, stretches himself across both seats and turns on his radi finds only static and snaps it off. Further depressed, he examines his reflection in the bus window, squeezes a bla head and runs the comb through his hair, picks a piece of tobacco off his tooth and lights a cigarette, watching th flame die in reflection, forgetting to discard the burnt- match as he stares out at a vast lonely prairie, a solita cowboy in the distance, a row of sharecropper shacks apparently deserted, a barefoot little girl motionless at roadside, watching the bus pass. Through this, leading in the next scene, Sally Buck sings softly "... if that mock bird don't sing, Grammaw gonna buy you a golden ring..."

Sally Buck, relaxing in the middle of a busy day, eyes cl wearily, while little Joe massages her neck. Her song continues over the noises of the busy beauty parlor "... that golden ring turns brass, Grammaw gonna buy you a loo glass..."
No, a little lower, sugar, yeah, yeah, that's good. Grammaw's beat.
You gotta sell yourself, that's the whole trick...

A seedy TRAVELING SALESMAN with badly-fitted dentures and frayed collar has taken the aisle seat next to Joe. As he lectures Joe on salesmanship, he figures his expenses in worn leatherette notebook, nervous fingers and eyes unconsciously revealing the extent of his failure.

It ain't the product and it ain't the price, no sir, and it ain't what you sell, it's personality, pure and simple. I ain't shined my own shoes or shaved my own face in forty years, how's that? Not bad for a kid that didn't pass the eighth grade, right?
Yeah, hell, yeah.
And that's my golden rule. Make 'em love you. Put yourself over and you can sell them anything. If they like you, they'll buy horsemeat for prime beef...
A gawky, adolescent Joe sits sprawled on the couch, leafi through a magazine while Sally Buck bleaches the roots of young woman's hair.
You get him to the church, honey. He ain't gonna find out you ain't a real blonde till after you're married, then's too late. Sally Buck turns, pretending to be stern as Toe laughs.
You getting too big for your britches, sugar.
The headlights of the bus flash past a huge sign, painted the slant roof of a barn: JESUS SAVES.

Joe is alone again. The Salesman has disappeared. The bus dark, most-passengers trying to sleep. Only one reading l still burns, over the head of the old-Lady in the seat ah of Joe. Joe squirms, restless, trying to lull himself to sleep with the music of a revivalist gospel group on the radio.

Don't forget to say your prayers, honey... Joe leans forward to help the old Lady, irritably struggl with the release button on her seat. She scowls as Joe le over to release her seat, then pulls her blanket around h and turns away from him. Joe switches off her reading lig

I want it on. Joe switches it on again, fakes a good-natured grin, sett back with his radio, aware of an OLD COWHAND seated oppos him, replacing the Pale Blonde. The Old Cowhand is apprai Joe's wardrobe curiously. He looks away when he sees Joe watching him. Joe settles back, unable to think of a way open a conversation.

Oh, my friends, I say unto you, invest with Jesus, put your dollars to work where they'll pay off at compound interest. The Good Book says money answereth all things... The Old Cowhand has rolled-himself a cigarette. Joe quick lights a match on his thumb and holds it across the aisle
Light? The Old Cowhand's "thanks" is lost in a fit of coughing a inhales his first drag. He settles back, wiping his water eyes on a faded bandana.
... everyone who sends a dollar to the Evangelical Congregation of the Air will get free gratis a genuine leatherette hymn book so you can sing along with Sister Rosella and the Evangelical Choir...
You throw in Sister Rosella and you got a deal, right, old timer? Joe glances across the aisle. The Old Cowhand manages a faint, humorless smile.
Going far?
Up the line. Not far.
I'm bound for New York City. The Old Cowhand reappraises Joe's wardrobe even more curiously.
Ever happen to come across a cowman name of Woodsy Niles? Friend of my grammaw Sally Buck... The Old Cowhand considers, shakes his head. Joe leans bac laughing to himself.

Little Joe's head is lost in a beat-up cowboy hat, simila the one worn by the old Cowhand. Sally Buck smiles on WOO NILES -- a long-legged cowboy with a shock of black hair who stands at her dressing table, admiring himself in a n Stetson.
Like it, honey? Does it fit?

You do me good, Sal, you do me real good. You know what I gonna give you for that Stetson? Woodsy grabs Sally Buck, lifting her off her feet, carryi her to the bed. Struggling, they fall across the covers together, Little Joe laughing with them.
Woodsy Niles! The boy!
He don't know what makes little apples by now, it's time he found out.
Joe shakes his head, grinning, offering the old Cowhand a cigarette.
Smoke? The old Cowhand shakes his head, showing the rolled cigar Joe lit for him. Joe nods, still bemused.
Little Joe is cuddled in Sally Buck's arms, under the cov watching Woodsy, sitting cross-legged on the bed, naked except for his Stetson and guitar, singing drunkenly.
... git along little dogies!
From a high angle -- the bus slows to a stop.

Joe awakens, stiff-necked, momentarily confused. He straightens in his seat as he sees the old Cowhand liftin sweat-stained saddle down from the overhead rack, startin toward the front of the bus. Joe calls after him.
Nice talking to you, old timer. Joe stuffs a stick of gum in his mouth, turns to wave at Old Cowhand through the window as the bus pulls away.
She-dogs squat, boy. He-dogs stand up and lift their leg...
Woodsy, in his new Stetson, watches Little Joe in his bea cowboy hat, trying to balance on one foot, one leg lifted front of the trough. Woodsy roars with laughter.
... but he-men stand and shoot from the hip.
Joe laughs, flushes, checks his hair in the mirror.
The bus streaks past a brightly-colored billboard -- IN N

head_text.subj: YORK, A WELCOME AWAITS YOU AT THE TIMES SQUARE PALACE HOT

text: Joe is now sitting in the wide rear seat, between two you MARINES and a group of VETERANS wearing campaign caps and convention buttons, passing a bottle, singing "From the B of Montezuma to the Shores of Tripoli..." Joe follows the conversation between a VETERAN and a MARINE, participatin only because he's sitting beside them, adopting a remembe military stance.
Ever stationed at Kennedy? Those Florida chicks...
Instant V-goddam-D.
This Pensacola teeny-bopper -- jail bait -- but built? Ten bucks she wanted. Three of us made a deal for, twenty-five, see, big goddam bargain?
Big peni-goddam-cillin bargain, right?
You got it.
No. You got it.
Jesus goddam Christ, I ain't laughed so hard since I was out at Fort Benning, Georgia.
Did you make the Viet?
What? Oh, hell no. Motor pool mostly... (shakes his head)
Kee-rist...
A plump, aging PROSTITUTE laughs up into camera.
Hey, hey, what you try to do to me? You gonna cost me money, soldier!
Joe laughs as he passes the bottle, trying to sing along without knowing the words as the Veterans segue into "Ove hill, over dale, we will hit the dusty trail, as the cais go rolling along..."
Sally Buck fondly wipes lipstick from Joe's lips.
Keep your meat hooks off my operators, sugar, hear?
Joe slaps one of the Veterans on the back, trying to foll the song into "Off we go, into the wild blue yonder..."
ANASTASIA clutches a younger Joe, eyes wild, gasping.
You're the only one, Joe, the only, only one ever!
Joe is leaning across the two Marines, staring out of the window as the Veterans switch to "Anchors aweigh, my boys anchors aweigh..."
A stunning view through the bus window past Joe's reflect
Gonna swing my lasso and rope that whole goddam island, yeah!
Drum majorettes leading the parade -- ticker tape and confetti -- girls at skyscraper windows.
Charles Lindberg (or James Stewart) waving at the crowd.
Girls lining the piers -- flags, banners, bunting -- ship horns, whistles, bells.
Joe crowded as the veterans prepare to leave the bus, lif down banners and flags.
The bus suddenly surrounded by converging traffic, horns honking, segueing into the noises of Times Square.
Flag draped, reading: WELCOME VETERANS.
Flapping in the wind -- WELCOME VETERANS!
The marquee announces TRANSIENTS WELCOME. O.S. a singing radio station break blares "W-I-N-S NEW YORK..."
The sign flashes WINS "... ten-ten on your dial!" A torch woman's voice sings from a lonely echo chamber -- introdu a love theme which will haunt Joe throughout the film.

Joe sets his radio on the dresser, his suitcase on the be then turns to examine his new home -- as anonymous as his Texas hotel room -- but boasting a coin-operated televisi set. Fascinated, Joe inserts a quarter. ... the love song continues over a television talk Show featuring a POODLE WIGMAKER defending his profession agai a Joe Pyne-type PANEL HOST, "...well, I perform a real service, there's a need, so many people, you know, really live in their pets, I mean, lonely, I grant you, but thei feeling is real. They want to lavish as much love, give t as much, yes, pamper them like they were really human children or whatever..."
There's a TV dinner in the fridge, lover boy...
Little Joe stares sullenly at an antique TV box while Sal Buck puts her hat on at the fireplace mirror. There is a framed picture of Woodsy Niles on the mantle.
You be okay, won't you? Maybe I bring you a treat if you're a good boy...
Joe watches the Panel Host, "... you're a nut case, fella real nut case..."
Little Joe massaging Sally Buck's neck -- continuing the earlier scene.
I'm so beat, no point you waiting round, toots, think I'll stop in for a beer or two...
Joe sits on the edge of the bed, watching the poodles pri
Little Joe stares unblinking at the TV screen as Sally Bu kisses him on the forehead, dressed for the street.

Expect me when you see me. Looks like I got me a new beau, lover boy, how's that for an old grammaw? I'll leave you movie money... Sally Buck tucks a dollar bill under a framed picture of Jesus, who has replaced Woodsy Niles on the mantle.

As a fairy godmother's magic wand removes sticky hair spr from a pretty model's head, Joe's quarter runs out and th screen goes blank. At the same moment, the love song is c off by a singing station break "W-I-N-S NEW YORK" Joe ris flipping the dial of the radio to a cultured woman's voic reading "...the Dow Jones averages, brought you by Morgan Vandercook. Up your income with sound investment counseling..."

Up yours, lady. ... but Joe leaves the lady on, savoring the expensive so of her voice reading the stock quotations. Joe seats hims at the desk, pleased to find a postcard photograph of the hotel. He picks up a ballpoint pen, counts ten floors up the street and marks a huge X -- THIS IS ME, then turns t card over, pen poised over the address blank.
Ralph stares at the card, surrounded by dirty dishes.
Hell, he know I can't read...
Joe's pen wavers, starts to write and stops.
As we saw it last, deserted, a FOR RENT sign in the windo Joe's reflection appears, staring at himself, dressed in dishwasher's clothes.
After all them dishes are washed, what?
Then they bring some more dishes and I wash them and then I, uh, sleep some and then wash some more dishes and then I...
Say it, lover boy!
Die.
Joe stares at the postcard, bemused,
Well, you better just shake your tail, lover boy, and root, hog or die. Joe rises abruptly, rips up the postcard and tosses it ou the window.
Goddam if I came to this town to write postcards.
The torn fragments flutter down on the crowd -- a woman brushing irritably at her hair -- a man grimacing, glanci up -- a cop removing his hat to examine it.
From a low angle -- identical with the postcard photograp an unseen hand scrawls a huge X--- THIS IS ME. Camera zoo up to a close-up of Joe at the window.
From on high -- as though Joe were watching himself -- th Stetson moves through a crowd of Fifth Avenue shoppers...
... passing a glass bank, lady tellers counting money...
... passing a display of imported luxury cars...

... passing a window which features a single gem -- pausi as horns blast O.S. and a mod blonde in a stalled sports motions to Joe -- she needs a push. Joe grins, glances at himself in the window, runs a comb through his hair, then turns back to see a cop helping the mod blonde.

Joe's heels drag as he walks a deserted block of luxury apartment houses. O.S. The torchy woman's voice sings Joe love theme in counterpoint to the blasting horns, a siren fire bell, a screech of brakes. Joe's spirits rise as he hears the tic-tac-tic of high heels overtaking the heavy click-clack-click of his boots. He adjusts his pace to ar at the corner at the same time as a smart and -- in Joe's eyes -- very RICH LADY. Joe grins boyishly, holding his Stetson over his heart.

Beg pardon, ma'am, I'm new here in town, just in from Houston, Texas, and looking for the Statue of Liberty. The delicate profile gives no signs of hearing. Joe follo her to the parkway in the middle of the avenue. There she stops and turns, neither friendly nor hostile.
Were you looking? About the Statue of Liberty?
Joking? No, ma'am. Oh no! I mean business!
I'm sorry. I thought you were -- never mind -- I've never actually been there, but let me see, you take the Seventh Avenue subway, I think, to the end of the line...
You sure are a pretty lady. The Rich Lady tries to frown, taken aback, blushing.
You're not looking for the Statue of Liberty at all.
No, ma'am, I'm not.

Why, that's perfectly dreadful. Aren't you ashamed of yourself? A twinkle of amusement and sympathy reveals the age lines the corner of her eyes. Then she continues on quickly, ju as the light turns. Joe's view is blocked for a moment by traffic, then he sees... ... the Rich Lady, newly aware of her flanks as she climb the steps of a brownstone and searches for her key. Still from Joe's viewpoint, he sees himself move into frame and follow the Rich Lady up the steps. The love theme swells as the Rich Lady leads him into the house and closes the door... ... leaving Joe standing alone on the parkway island, surrounded by towering wealth. The love theme continues over...
... a pair of high-heeled pink slippers, walking a miniat poodle -- slowing slightly, reacting to Joe's cowboy boot they pass, pause and turn back.

Hurry up, Baby. Do um goody-goods for Mama. Joe grins, holding his hat over his heart as he approache CASS TREHUNE, a blonde lady in a tight black dress, with look of a movie star who wrecked her career with food.
Beg pardon, ma'am. I'm brand spanking new to this town, come  from Houston, Texas, and hoping to get a look at the Statue of Liberty...
You're hoping to get a look at what?
The Statue of Liberty.
It's up in Central Park, taking a leak. If you hurry, you'll make the supper show. Now get lost. But as she turns, Cass winks, dimpling the corners of her mouth, signaling Joe to follow her.
Cass holds the DOOR OPEN button till Joe enters the eleva then the doors close with a soft expensive little kllooos and Cass turns with the smile of a very tiny girl...

Hi. ... her lips closing on Joe's as the poodle yaps shrilly their feet. Superimposed, almost subliminally, a golden dollar sign appears, halating like a star, and the bell o pinball machine rings O.S.
A princess telephone is ringing on a gold and white desk. Cass runs to grab it...

Hello? ... as Joe steps from the elevator, which opens directly Cass's penthouse. Cass beckons him toward her, hooks a fi into his neckerchief and pulls his mouth toward hers whil she talks on the phone.
Morey? Hi-ee, honey... Cass gurgles happily as her free hand unbuckles Joe's garrison belt.
I'm just out of breath, honey, running to catch the phone. As her fingers reach for Joe's zipper, cut to... ... Joe's hand unzipping her dress.
I was walking Baby. Him got to do him goody-goods, right? The poodle tugs at Joe's slacks until they fall. Cass ste her ear to Joe's mouth, shuddering deliciously.
Oh God, oh stop. I can't stand that. I just die... (quickly into phone)

It's Baby, Morey. Him trying to say hello. Say hello to Morey, Baby. Cass holds the phone toward the yapping poodle, twisting herself against Joe as she wriggles out of her dress, pas the phone from one hand to the other.

Okay, old goosie? Now lookie, when do you want me to meet you? Whatever you say. I'll take a nap, watch TV, you know, kill time. Okay, but just one, a big wet one. Cass hangs up. The poodle yaps hysterically, disentanglin himself from her tumbling dress -- hops onto the couch  glances off and flees again as an overturned lamp crashes O.S.

The poodle bounces onto the bed -- remaining long enough establish a TV REMOTE CONTROL TUNER lying on the satin coverlet -- then leaps down in panic as he hears Joe and explode into the bedroom, laughing lustily... ... the remote control tuner buried suddenly under the fu flesh of Cass's hip, activating... ... a twenty-five-inch television screen, blasting at ful volume... ... Cass's eyes widening, profoundly impressed...

Ye gods... ... the images and sound of the television set flicking joyfully from channel to channel... ... Joe laughing, engulfed by Cass's abundance... ... Cass wild-eyed, overflowing the frame... ... a gleaming slot machine -- three Sahara cowgirls clic into line for jackpot -- silver dollars overflowing the frame...
... the Mutual of New York tower flashes MONY!
Holy shee-it, this is a goddam penthouse you got here, Cass, a real goddam penthouse.

Joe turns away from a small terrace, buckling his belt, glancing off toward the sound of Cass in the shower. He flicks the TV remote control, enjoying his power, ignorin the silent images on the screen -- battle casualties, a pretty girl recommending aspirin, a man's stomach flashin animated pain, starving war refugees, a dog eating pzazz flicking it off to concentrate on the costume jewelry and perfume bottles on Cass's dressing table.
Don't look, baby... Joe turns to look as Cass comes from the bathroom, holdin towel around her as she runs behind the closet door.
Say, Cass, I, uh, sure have enjoyed being here. Believe it's as fine a time as I've had in my life!
Me, too, lover.
That's good, it is, cause, well I guess I didn't tell you why I came to New York, did I? A tower of black bugle beads emerges from the closet door
Zip this thing, will you, Tex? Joe zips her dress, follows her to the dressing table, wh she sprays her hair with lacquer.
Truth is, Cass, I'm, well, I'm in business.
Oh, poor you. Morey's got terrible ulcers. Cass stretches her upper lip across her teeth and she sme it with, orange lipstick.
Don't know what line Morey's in, but myself now, fact is -- I'm a hustler.
(lips stretched)
Hers'n zodda meg a livig.
Beg pardon, ma'am?
Said, a person's gotta make a living.
You sure you heard what I said?

Scuse me, hon, fraid I'm only half here. Maybe you oughta run on along. But why don't you take this phone number? Joe grins, relieved as she takes out a gold lame purse an opens it. He frowns as she folds; it upside down, empty.
Darn! I didn't get to the bank -- Tex -- could you let me have a little coin for the taxi-waxi? Joe stands mute as she cups his chin in her hand, seductively.
You're such a doll. I hate money, don't you? God, it's been fun.
Funny thing, you mentioning money. I was just about to ask your for some... Joe tries to laugh but it sticks in his throat as Cass sp -- an impassioned whisper -- still holding Joe's chin.

You bastard! You son of a bitch! You think you're dealing with some old slut? Look at me! You think just cause you're a longhorn bull you can get away with this crap? Well, you're out of your mind. I am a gorgeous chick, thirty-one, that's right, you said it! Sobbing suddenly, she throws herself on the bed. Joe stan bewildered by the vastness of her grief.

Hey. Hey, Cass. Did you think I meant that? Christ, would I be asking you for money with a wad like that riding on my hip? Joe waves his wallet at her, but she only cries louder. H hands her a kleenex. She clutches it to her face, wailing Joe leans over the bed, whispering in her ear:

Hey. You are a gorgeous-looking piece, Cass. Guy gets horny, just looking at you. It's a fact. How much you need for that taxi? Ten? Twenty? There you go. Joe tucks a twenty-dollar bill into her bosom, tilts his Stetson and starts out. Cass blows her nose, looking afte him. O.S. chorus sings, "From this valley they say you ar going -- we will miss your bright eyes and sweet smile...
From a high angle, Joe walks away from the apartment hous chorus continuing O.S. "... they say you are taking the sunshine that brightened our pathway a while."
Joe sits at the bar, staring morosely at his image in the mirror, already quite drunk, oblivious to the assorted ty hiding from daylight in the barn-like saloon, waiting for night to fall.

Excuse me, I'm just admiring that colossal shirt... RATSO studies Joe across the corner of the bar -- a sickl child-size old man of twenty-one -- hopefully nursing an empty beer glass, contemplating the money on the bar in f of Joe.
That is one hell of a shirt. I bet you paid a pretty price for it, am I right?

Oh, it ain't cheap. I mean, yeah, I'd say this was an all right shirt. Don't like to, uh, you know, have a lot of cheap stuff on my back. Ratso spits as JACKIE leans on the bar next to Joe -- a feminine young person, heavily made-up, hair teased, wear earrings and a lace-trimmed blouse over shocking pink  le
Got a cigarette, cowboy?
(a stage whisper)
More goddam faggots in this town. Reaching for a cigarette, Joe glances at Jackie, startled Jackie twitches his pink levis angrily and turns away.
Shee-it... (shakes his head)
Kee-rist, you really know the ropes. Wish to hell I bumped into you before. I'm Joe Buck from Texas and I'm gonna buy you a drink, what do you say to that?
Enrico Rizzo from the Bronx. Don't mind if I do.
(slaps bar)

Same all around! For my friend, too! The TV screen over the bar features a mating game program Jackie cruises down to join a tall farm boy with plucked eyebrows. The TV HOST points to three young men, visible from the shoulders up, from whom a pretty DATE GIRL in blindfold must choose an escort.
